item.item_label: How to wash your hands the right way?
Is there anything else I can do?
What are the symptoms of Covid-19?

screen_id.keywords: Desk, Office, Work, Computer, PC, Keybord, Documents

screen.Content:
You are participating in this e-learning course because you are interested in coronavirus and it’s prevention, and would like to know what steps to take in order to minimise the risk of exposure to you, your family, and others within your community.

Should you have accessibility issues all text can be read by a screen reader and text is vocalised by the presenter or voiceover in most cases.

screen_id.keywords: Work, Sky, City, Skyline, Building, Board, White, Presentation

screen.Content:
Welcome to this learning session about Coronavirus. In this course we shall address:

• What is Covid-19?

• How to protect yourself and others?

• What is self-isolation and why is it important?

This module will take 20 minutes and there will be a few quick questions at the end to check how you’ve got on.

What is a coronavirus?

Coronaviruses are a family of viruses which cause disease in animals. Sometimes, as in this case, a virus can mutate and jump from animals to humans (as is the case here) and cause infection.

This coronavirus has been named Covid-19, and since it first appeared in China, has now spread to over 110 countries around the globe.

screen_id.keywords: Help, Desk, Person, Consultation, Advice, Silhouette, Office, Work

screen.Content: There are many misconceptions surrounding the Covid-19 virus. Press below to learn more - knowing the truth could stop you getting infected and save lives.

It is mutating!

It is common belief that Covid-19 is mutating into a more deadly strain.

Viruses mutate all the time and there is currently no evidence that any new mutations are more or less dangerous than what has gone on before.

It is no more dangerous than winter flu?

Currently the WHO estimates approximately a 1% fatality rate.

This would make Covid-19 about 10 times more deadly than seasonal flu, which is estimated to kill between 290,000 and 650,000 people a year globally. SInce there is no vaccine this makes the disease particularly dangerous.

It only kills the old

Regardless of your age, you have a responsibility to society to not spread the disease. It is true to say that the older you, the more chance you have of succumbing to the disease.

It is also true that those with an underlying health condition or health workers (who have a higher exposure to the virus) are also at greater risk.

It’s largely spread through contaminated surfaces

Good hygiene is important to prevent the virus being transmitted from surfaces, but this does seem to be relatively rare. Hospital guidelines for winter flu define exposure as being within six feet of an infected person who sneezes or coughs for 10 minutes or longer. For this reason sharing a flight, or similar confined space seems to be a common method of infection.

A vaccine could be ready within a few months

To prepare a vaccine is a monumental task and releasing an untested vaccine could cause side effects far worse than the cure.

Do not expect a vaccine in 2020 - mid 2021 would be more realistic.

I should stockpile goods at home?

If you fear Covid 19 will lead to a food shortage, then panic buying and stockpiling food will potentially create the problem that you are afraid of.

It is highly unlikely that food delivery services will stop and the government has made preparations in case of this emergency. Covid-19 is not deadly enough to completely prevent food getting through to you.

I can catch it from a passing pedestrian?

You need to be in close proximity to someone for an extended period of time or have touched a surface that has been contaminated.

In other words when walking around in the open air it is highly unlikely you will catch the disease.

Summer will kill the virus.

It is unlikely that this is true. Summer in the northern hemisphere will however lead to people being outdoors and not so often in close proximity.

This should have a beneficial effect in slowing the disease.
Most viruses are transmitted in small droplets of water which are expelled during coughs and sneezes. The best way to prevent coronavirus is to effectively capturing coughs and sneezes.
The virus can also live on contaminated surfaces. For these reasons regular handwashing and cleaning of surfaces is also important.

Viruses can also transmit through the eyes and tiny particles can even penetrate masks - however masks are effective at capturing droplets, which is a main transmission route of coronavirus, and some studies have estimated a roughly fivefold protection versus no barrier alone.
Masks are crucial for those looking after someone who is ill or for the patient to prevent infection.

Masks will probably make little difference however if you’re just walking around town.

I short - do not panic if you do not have a mask. There is no need to bulk buy a supply!

Masks could even be a hazard!

A mask could collect the virus on it whilst being worn which could then contaminate hands when removing it.

If you are using a mask always wash your hands afterwards.

screen_id.keywords: Work, Sky, City, Skyline, Building, Board, White, Presentation

screen.Section: How to wash your hands the right way?
screen.Content: According to the World Health Organisation, to wash your hands properly should take about as long as singing “Happy Birthday” twice.
Following the steps below will make sure hands are washed properly ...

screen.Section: Is there anything else I can do?
screen.Content:
There are some things you can do now to help prevent the spread of Covid-19.

Press the next button below to see the steps you can take...

Avoid Shaking Hands

Shaking hands and kissing people on the cheek.

Approach people with a fist pump or an outstretched elbow.

Make this the new normal!

Avoid touching your face

Touching your face causes the transmission of any virus from a contaminated surface into the eyes or mouth.

Identify triggers such as runny nose or urge to sneeze which cause you to touch your face. Make sure you have a tissue close by, it's better to use that to touch your face than bare hands.

Vaccinate against the flu

It is likely that the medical services will be under pressure during a Covid-19 outbreak.

Getting a flu vaccination will not protect you from Covid-19, but it will alleviate the pressure on the health services.

Avoid travel

Avoid travelling to outbreak hotspots such as:

• China

• Italy

• South Korea

Monitor the spread of the disease accordingly. Also avoid taking unnecessary flights which will cause you to be in a confined space with potential carriers for a long period of time.

Follow government advice

This is particularly relevant if there is a request for the general public to not gather in large groups, travel or to self isolate.

Such measures can stop the virus in a very short period of time if everybody acts together.

screen.Section: What are the symptoms of Covid-19?
screen.Content:
OK - so lets say you have taken the necessary precautions, but regardless you fear you may have contacted the virus.

Let's first look at the symptoms you should be aware of that could indicate you might have the virus?

Symptoms

Symptoms related to Covid 19 include:

• Fever and abnormal tiredness

• Coughing and sneezing

• Breathing difficulties

• Muscle pain

Close contact

If you have been within 2 metres of someone diagnosed with Covid-19 for 15 minutes or more, it would be classed as “close contact” and you should be extremely vigilant for symptoms.

Similarly, if you have tested positive for Covid-19, you should make sure all of those you have been in close contact with are notified by the health authorities.

Contact

If you are either experiencing symptoms or have been in close contact with someone who has the virus then you should dial 111 (UK only) or visit https://111.nhs.uk/covid-19.

DO NOT go to a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital.

Do call emergency services should there be a medical emergency.

screen_id.keywords: Building, House, Safety, Office, Door, Work

screen.Content: If you have travelled to an affected area, or have been in close contact with someone who was infected, you might be asked to self-isolate by the health authorities.
To self-isolate means staying at home for 14 days - do not go to work, school or other public places (including shops, restaurants or similar) and avoid public transport or taxies.
Keep yourself away from others within your home, in a well ventilated room unless absolutely necessary. Do ask for help should you need it for groceries, other shopping or medication.

Do not share towels, toiletries or other similar items.

If you cannot use a separate bathroom, you should use the shared one last, and if able, clean it thoroughly after.
Avoid using the kitchen at the same time as other people in your home, and eat meals in your room.
Having friends, family or delivery drivers off supplies to you is okay, but you should not have any visitors. Ask for all deliveries to be left on your doorstep.

Any rubbish/trash that you have been in contact with should be double-bagged and kept.

If you are subsequently tested positive, the health authorities will instruct you what to do with it.
If you reside in the UK and are not self-employed, then you will still get paid.
Emergency rules have dictated that workers will be paid statutory sick pay (£94.25 per week) from the first day of illness.

If you need to care for a relative, or your child’s school is closed and you must look after them, your employer must give you time off, but it may be unpaid.

It is important that any children are not looked after by elderly relatives as they are particularly at risk.

Congratulations you have now completed the course on Covid-19. You should now know ...

• What is Covid-19?

• How to protect yourself and others?

• What is self-isolation and why is it important?
